summary: This is a discovery letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to the defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, providing an index of materials (Bates-stamped SDNY_GM_00000001 through SDNY_GM_00012841) being disclosed pursuant to Rule 16. It outlines the scope of discovery, requests reciprocal discovery, and states the government's policies on plea offers and sentencing reductions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). The document is a discovery letter addressed to her counsel.

connections.description: The discovery index includes joint records (immigration, travel, Google accounts) and materials pertaining to both, indicating a close association central to the investigation.
Everdell is listed as receiving this discovery letter as one of Maxwell's defense attorneys.
Cohen is listed as receiving this discovery letter as one of Maxwell's defense attorneys.
Indyke is listed as an executor of Epstein's estate; discovery includes materials from him.
Kahn is listed as an executor of Epstein's estate; discovery includes materials from him.
Discovery includes flight manifests and records from David Rodgers spanning 1991-2013, indicating a long-term travel association.

events.title: Government Provides Discovery to Maxwell Defense
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sends a formal discovery letter and index of materials (over 12,000 items) to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team.

events.title: Protective Order Issued
events.description: A protective order is issued in the case, governing the handling of confidential discovery materials.

keyFacts: The government is providing extensive discovery in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell, comprising over 12,800 Bates-stamped items (SDNY_GM_00000001 through SDNY_GM_00012841).

The discovery index reveals the vast scope of the investigation, including financial records (banks, PayPal, Venmo), travel records (airlines, flight manifests), communications data (AT&T, Google, Apple), and corporate records for entities like LSJ LLC, Laurel Inc, Maple Inc, and Nautilus, Inc.
The government formally requests reciprocal discovery from Maxwell's defense team, including books, reports, and prior witness statements they intend to use.

The letter states the government will oppose an additional sentencing guideline reduction for acceptance of responsibility if Maxwell does not plead guilty at least six weeks before trial or before the provision of 3500 material.
The document clarifies that any plea offer must be in writing and signed by authorized representatives of the U.S. Attorney's Office to be considered formal.
